trans-unit.source: How to Use docker-machine with Azure
trans-unit.target: How to Use docker-machine with Azure

trans-unit.source: Shows how to get up and running on Azure with Docker Machine on Ubuntu.
trans-unit.target: Shows how to get up and running on Azure with Docker Machine on Ubuntu.

trans-unit.source: How to use docker-machine with Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use docker-machine with Azure

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how to use <link><linkText>Docker</linkText><title></title></link> with <link><linkText>machine</linkText><title></title></link> and the <link><linkText>Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link> to create an Azure Virtual Machine to quickly and easily manage Linux containers from a computer running Ubuntu.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how to use <link><linkText>Docker</linkText><title></title></link> with <link><linkText>machine</linkText><title></title></link> and the <link><linkText>Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link> to create an Azure Virtual Machine to quickly and easily manage Linux containers from a computer running Ubuntu.

trans-unit.source: To demonstrate, the tutorial shows how to deploy both the <link><linkText>busybox Docker Hub image</linkText><title></title></link> image and also the <link><linkText>nginx Docker Hub image</linkText><title></title></link> and configures the container to route web requests to the nginx container.
trans-unit.target: To demonstrate, the tutorial shows how to deploy both the <link><linkText>busybox Docker Hub image</linkText><title></title></link> image and also the <link><linkText>nginx Docker Hub image</linkText><title></title></link> and configures the container to route web requests to the nginx container.

trans-unit.source: (The Docker machine documentation describes how to modify these instructions for other platforms.)
trans-unit.target: (The Docker machine documentation describes how to modify these instructions for other platforms.)

trans-unit.source: There are some prerequisites for completing this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: There are some prerequisites for completing this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You will need to install the following:
trans-unit.target: You will need to install the following:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>npm</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Node.js</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>npm</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Node.js</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>The Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>The Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: A <link><linkText>Docker client</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: A <link><linkText>Docker client</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: If you install those items in that order, your Ubuntu computer will be ready for the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: If you install those items in that order, your Ubuntu computer will be ready for the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: (This tutorial should be largely the same for any other dpkg-based distro such as Debian.
trans-unit.target: (This tutorial should be largely the same for any other dpkg-based distro such as Debian.

trans-unit.source: Let us know in comments if you discover extra requirements or steps.)
trans-unit.target: Let us know in comments if you discover extra requirements or steps.)

trans-unit.source: Get docker-machine -- or build it
trans-unit.target: Get docker-machine -- or build it

trans-unit.source: The quickest way to get going with docker-machine is to download the appropriate release directly from the release share.
trans-unit.target: The quickest way to get going with docker-machine is to download the appropriate release directly from the release share.

trans-unit.source: The client computer in this tutorial was running Ubuntu on an x64 computer, so the docker-machine_linux-amd64 image is the one used.
trans-unit.target: The client computer in this tutorial was running Ubuntu on an x64 computer, so the docker-machine_linux-amd64 image is the one used.

trans-unit.source: You can also build your docker-machine yourself by following the steps for contributing to machine.
trans-unit.target: You can also build your docker-machine yourself by following the steps for contributing to machine.

trans-unit.source: You should be ready to download as much as 1 GB or more to perform the build, but by doing so you can customize your experience precisely the way you want.
trans-unit.target: You should be ready to download as much as 1 GB or more to perform the build, but by doing so you can customize your experience precisely the way you want.

trans-unit.source: You might well create a <link><linkText>symbolic link</linkText><title></title></link> to your platform version of it, but this tutorial uses the binary directly to demonstrate behavior very clearly.
trans-unit.target: You might well create a <link><linkText>symbolic link</linkText><title></title></link> to your platform version of it, but this tutorial uses the binary directly to demonstrate behavior very clearly.

trans-unit.source: The result is that instead of commands such as docker-machine env as the docker-machine documentation shows, this tutorial uses docker-machine_linux-amd64 env instead.
trans-unit.target: The result is that instead of commands such as docker-machine env as the docker-machine documentation shows, this tutorial uses docker-machine_linux-amd64 env instead.

trans-unit.source: Whether you create a symlink or just use the binary name directly is up to you, but if you change the name you are using, remember to modify the name in the instructions below.
trans-unit.target: Whether you create a symlink or just use the binary name directly is up to you, but if you change the name you are using, remember to modify the name in the instructions below.

trans-unit.source: Whichever method you choose, you must either call in the binary directly on the command line or place the binary the path such as /usr/local/bin.
trans-unit.target: Whichever method you choose, you must either call in the binary directly on the command line or place the binary the path such as /usr/local/bin.

trans-unit.source: Remember to make sure it is marked as executable by typing chmod +x <*binaryName> where <binaryName*> is the name of your Docker machine executable.
trans-unit.target: Remember to make sure it is marked as executable by typing chmod +x <*binaryName> where <binaryName*> is the name of your Docker machine executable.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses docker-machine_linux-amd64.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses docker-machine_linux-amd64.

trans-unit.source: Create the certificate and key files for docker, machine, and Azure
trans-unit.target: Create the certificate and key files for docker, machine, and Azure

trans-unit.source: Now you must create the certificate and key files that Azure needs to confirm your identity and permissions as well as those docker-machine needs to communicate with your Azure Virtual Machine to create and manage containers remotely.
trans-unit.target: Now you must create the certificate and key files that Azure needs to confirm your identity and permissions as well as those docker-machine needs to communicate with your Azure Virtual Machine to create and manage containers remotely.

trans-unit.source: If you already have these files in a directory -- perhaps for use with docker -- you can reuse them.
trans-unit.target: If you already have these files in a directory -- perhaps for use with docker -- you can reuse them.

trans-unit.source: However, the best practice for testing docker-machine would be to create them in a separate directory and point docker-machine at them.
trans-unit.target: However, the best practice for testing docker-machine would be to create them in a separate directory and point docker-machine at them.

trans-unit.source: If you end up trying docker-machine over and over again, be sure to either reuse the same certificate and key files.
trans-unit.target: If you end up trying docker-machine over and over again, be sure to either reuse the same certificate and key files.

trans-unit.source: docker-machine creates a set of client certs as well -- everything it creates can be examined in ~/.docker/machine.
trans-unit.target: docker-machine creates a set of client certs as well -- everything it creates can be examined in ~/.docker/machine.

trans-unit.source: If you move those certs to another computer, you'll need to move the docker-machine certificate folders as well.
trans-unit.target: If you move those certs to another computer, you'll need to move the docker-machine certificate folders as well.

trans-unit.source: This makes a difference if you're going to use docker-machine on another platform, for example, just to see how it all works.
trans-unit.target: This makes a difference if you're going to use docker-machine on another platform, for example, just to see how it all works.

trans-unit.source: If you have experience with Linux distributions, you may already have these files available to use on your computer in a specific place, and the <link><linkText>Docker HTTPS documentation explains these steps well</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you have experience with Linux distributions, you may already have these files available to use on your computer in a specific place, and the <link><linkText>Docker HTTPS documentation explains these steps well</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: However, the following is the simplest form of this step.
trans-unit.target: However, the following is the simplest form of this step.

trans-unit.source: Create a local folder and on the command-line, navigate to that folder and type:
trans-unit.target: Create a local folder and on the command-line, navigate to that folder and type:

trans-unit.source: Be ready here to enter the export password for your certificate and capture it for future usage.
trans-unit.target: Be ready here to enter the export password for your certificate and capture it for future usage.

trans-unit.source: Then type:
trans-unit.target: Then type:

trans-unit.source: Upload your certificate's .cer file to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Upload your certificate's .cer file to Azure.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Portal, click Settings in the bottom left of the service area (shown below)
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Portal, click Settings in the bottom left of the service area (shown below)

trans-unit.source: and then click Management Certificates:
trans-unit.target: and then click Management Certificates:

trans-unit.source: and then Upload (at the bottom of the page) to upload the mycert.cer file you created in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: and then Upload (at the bottom of the page) to upload the mycert.cer file you created in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: In the same Settings pane in the portal, click Subscriptions and capture the subscription ID to use when creating your VM, because you'll use it in the next step.
trans-unit.target: In the same Settings pane in the portal, click Subscriptions and capture the subscription ID to use when creating your VM, because you'll use it in the next step.

trans-unit.source: (You can also locate the subscription id on the command line using the Azure CLI command azure account list, which displays the subscription id for each subscription you have in the account.)
trans-unit.target: (You can also locate the subscription id on the command line using the Azure CLI command azure account list, which displays the subscription id for each subscription you have in the account.)

trans-unit.source: Create a docker host VM on Azure using the docker-machine create command.
trans-unit.target: Create a docker host VM on Azure using the docker-machine create command.

trans-unit.source: The command requires the subscription ID you just captured in the previous step and the path to the .pem file you created in step 1.
trans-unit.target: The command requires the subscription ID you just captured in the previous step and the path to the .pem file you created in step 1.

trans-unit.source: This topic uses "machine-name" as the Azure Cloud Service (and your VM) name, but you should replace that with your own choice and remember to use your cloud service name in any other step that requires the vm name.
trans-unit.target: This topic uses "machine-name" as the Azure Cloud Service (and your VM) name, but you should replace that with your own choice and remember to use your cloud service name in any other step that requires the vm name.

trans-unit.source: (Remember that in this example, we are using the full binary name and not a docker-machine symlink.)
trans-unit.target: (Remember that in this example, we are using the full binary name and not a docker-machine symlink.)

trans-unit.source: As the first two steps require the creation of a new VM and the loading of the Linux Azure agent as well as the updating of the new VM, you should see something like the following.
trans-unit.target: As the first two steps require the creation of a new VM and the loading of the Linux Azure agent as well as the updating of the new VM, you should see something like the following.

trans-unit.source: Because a VM is being created, it may take a few minutes to be in a ready state.
trans-unit.target: Because a VM is being created, it may take a few minutes to be in a ready state.

trans-unit.source: While you're waiting, you can check the state of your new Docker host by typing azure vm list using the Azure CLI until you see your VMs with the ReadyRole status.
trans-unit.target: While you're waiting, you can check the state of your new Docker host by typing azure vm list using the Azure CLI until you see your VMs with the ReadyRole status.

trans-unit.source: Set the docker and machine environment variables for the terminal session.
trans-unit.target: Set the docker and machine environment variables for the terminal session.

trans-unit.source: The last line of feedback suggest that you immediately run the env command to export the environment variables necessary to use your docker client directly with a specific machine.
trans-unit.target: The last line of feedback suggest that you immediately run the env command to export the environment variables necessary to use your docker client directly with a specific machine.

trans-unit.source: Once you do so, you do not need any special commands to use your local docker client to connect to the VM that Docker machine created.
trans-unit.target: Once you do so, you do not need any special commands to use your local docker client to connect to the VM that Docker machine created.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows docker-machine creating one VM. However, you can repeat the steps to create as many machines as you want. If you do so, the best way to switch between VMs with docker is to use the env command inline to set the docker environment variables for each individual command. For example, to use docker info with a different VM, you can type docker $(docker-machine env ) info and the env command fills in the docker connection information to use with that VM.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows docker-machine creating one VM. However, you can repeat the steps to create as many machines as you want. If you do so, the best way to switch between VMs with docker is to use the env command inline to set the docker environment variables for each individual command. For example, to use docker info with a different VM, you can type docker $(docker-machine env ) info and the env command fills in the docker connection information to use with that VM.

trans-unit.source: We're done. Let's run some applications remotely using docker and images from the Docker Hub.
trans-unit.target: We're done. Let's run some applications remotely using docker and images from the Docker Hub.

trans-unit.source: You can now use docker in the normal way to create an application in the container.
trans-unit.target: You can now use docker in the normal way to create an application in the container.

trans-unit.source: The easiest to demonstrate is <link><linkText>busybox</linkText><title></title></link>:
trans-unit.target: The easiest to demonstrate is <link><linkText>busybox</linkText><title></title></link>:

trans-unit.source: However, you may want to create an application that you can see immediately on the internet, such as the <link><linkText>nginx</linkText><title></title></link> from the <link><linkText>Docker Hub</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: However, you may want to create an application that you can see immediately on the internet, such as the <link><linkText>nginx</linkText><title></title></link> from the <link><linkText>Docker Hub</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Remember to use the -P option to have docker assign random ports to the image, and -d to ensure that the container runs in the background continuously.
trans-unit.target: Remember to use the -P option to have docker assign random ports to the image, and -d to ensure that the container runs in the background continuously.

trans-unit.source: (If you forget, you'll start nginx and then it will immediately shut down.
trans-unit.target: (If you forget, you'll start nginx and then it will immediately shut down.

trans-unit.source: Don't forget!)
trans-unit.target: Don't forget!)

trans-unit.source: To see it from the internet, create a public endpoint on port 80 for the Azure VM and map that port to the nginx container's port.
trans-unit.target: To see it from the internet, create a public endpoint on port 80 for the Azure VM and map that port to the nginx container's port.

trans-unit.source: First, use docker ps -a to locate the container and find which ports docker has assigned to the container's port 80.
trans-unit.target: First, use docker ps -a to locate the container and find which ports docker has assigned to the container's port 80.

trans-unit.source: (Below the displayed information is edited to show only port information; you'll see more.)
trans-unit.target: (Below the displayed information is edited to show only port information; you'll see more.)

trans-unit.source: We can see that docker has assigned the container's port 80 to the VM's port 49153.
trans-unit.target: We can see that docker has assigned the container's port 80 to the VM's port 49153.

trans-unit.source: We can now use the Azure CLI to map the external Cloud Service's public port 80 to port 49153 on the VM.
trans-unit.target: We can now use the Azure CLI to map the external Cloud Service's public port 80 to port 49153 on the VM.

trans-unit.source: Docker then ensures that inbound tcp traffic on VM port 49153 is routed to the nginx container.
trans-unit.target: Docker then ensures that inbound tcp traffic on VM port 49153 is routed to the nginx container.

trans-unit.source: Open your favorite browser and have a look.
trans-unit.target: Open your favorite browser and have a look.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Go to the <link><linkText>Docker user guide</linkText><title></title></link> and create some applications on Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: Go to the <link><linkText>Docker user guide</linkText><title></title></link> and create some applications on Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: Or, go play with <link><linkText>**docker** and swarm</linkText><title></title></link> on Azure](virtual-machines-docker-swarm) and see how swarm can be used with docker and Azure.
trans-unit.target: Or, go play with <link><linkText>**docker** and swarm</linkText><title></title></link> on Azure](virtual-machines-docker-swarm) and see how swarm can be used with docker and Azure.
